video.title: Dragon Age: The Veilguard | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Dragon Age: Veilguard?

It certainly has been a dragging age
since we last saw this franchise;
let&#39;s hope it doesn&#39;t fail hard

as certain parties prophesized
from its first trailer,
which was deeply magenta tinged,

and all characters being introduced
with Dutch angle freeze-frames and smug

looks to camera like a cross between
a hero shooter, a Cockney gangster film,

and a Lord of the Rings-themed
McDonalds Happy Meal campaign.
And I suppose a lot of people felt

that this was going against Dragon
Age&#39;s established identity, as, errrrr...
well, not that.

I remember way back when
dinosaurs ruled the earth,

the first Dragon Age game was
marketed as a &quot;dark fantasy.”

Ooh, take me seriously, mum, the
elves and dwarves are all being racist

and the wizards are all undergoing
treatment for self-harm.

So the Veilguard trailer gave
everyone that same cringey
feeling one got at school assembly

whenever a church group got
onto stage in colorful t-shirts

and started rapping about
Jesus, but let&#39;s face it,
Dragon Age has never had

much of a consistent identity beyond
&quot;BioWare&#39;s generic fantasy thing

that isn&#39;t Mass Effect,&quot; and
while Veilguard&#39;s slightly

more cartoonish, exaggerated art style
makes it feel more like a Fable game,

and as such, causes images
of Peter Molyneux to intrude

upon my mind&#39;s eye while I&#39;m
trying to jerk off to the love scenes,

it has kinda licked the
whole BioWare Face issue.

Effort seems to have gone
into making conversations

feel more expressive and animate
and not just dead-eyed backing

and forthing like your
parents having sex.

Keep this up, BioWare, and I&#39;m officially
renaming it to Bethesda Face.

Now, let&#39;s work on making
your dialogue less shit.
Less is more, guys.
&quot;What&#39;s that, Yahtz?
Relent-less verbal diarrhea is more?
We agree; have another glass.&quot;

Anyway, Veilguard is yet
another RPG struggling
with the eternal dilemma

of having full voice acting versus
letting you enter your character&#39;s name

and uses the common strategy of asking
you your name and then going, &quot;Psych!

No it isn&#39;t. Your name&#39;s
Rook.&quot; Rook is recruited

by established series character Varric
to stop a ritual to destroy the world,

and predictably enough,
shit goes a bit fucky.

Varric gets stabbed, some
evil elven gods escape

from the Phantom Zone or
whatever, and now it&#39;s up to us

to go through the typical BioWare
RPG motions: assemble a team,

save the world, pick a member
of the team to knob.
Not necessarily in that order.
Oh, Varric doesn&#39;t die, by the way.

I wonder if in some version of
events he was supposed to,

&#39;cos certain other NPCs keep
talking about avenging Varric

and doing it for Varric, but
he&#39;s fine; he&#39;s in the sickbay

scoffing grapes, being useless, so I
don&#39;t know what we&#39;re avenging here.
Bedsores, maybe.
This is just the beginning

of a general sense of shakiness
about Flagging Aged: Verybland,

like a budget self-assembled chair
that you can assure yourself is firm

as long as you never
try to lean back in it.

After the prologue, it goes from
you getting knocked out

while fucking up the ritual to you
waking up in a secret Power Rangers

headquarters in a pocket dimension
and the game going, &quot;Oh, hi!
This is where you live now.

Pick a bedroom and remember
to launder the hand towels.&quot;

And I feel like the story&#39;s
skipped a few steps.
Why is it on us to save the world?

We&#39;re just some dude Varric
hired for one job to hold the coats.

Yes, we&#39;re partially to
blame for the apocalypse

and we hear the voice of the less
evil elven god in our head,

but that doesn&#39;t mean anyone
else should take us seriously.
If the voices in my head

told me to set fire to my house, I&#39;d still
consider the fire brigade more qualified
to deal with it.

In the process of gathering our
party and venturing forth,

we visit various different
lands and the factions

that control them, and there&#39;s
this one chief of Grey Wardens

we&#39;re supposed to think is a
complete asshat &#39;cos he takes one
look at us and goes, &quot;I&#39;m sorry,

who the fuck are you, and
why are you talking to me?&quot;

But that was the one dude whose
attitude made any fucking sense.

The way everyone else immediately
trusts you to rescue their villagers

and assassinate their sworn
enemies, it only works

if you assume they know you&#39;re
the protagonist of the game.

Like they noticed the
mini-map and objective list
dangling from the stick tied to your head.

The shakiness also extends
to the world itself.

The way you have to fast travel
everywhere makes everything feel

small and disconnected—shall
we just start calling that

“Starfield Syndrome”?—
and the areas you go to,

most of them feel like they
designed a little labyrinth

of cramped corridors,
carved out one section of it

for all the NPCs and shops and quest-givers
to live in, and randomly sprinkled

combats and hidden
treasures across the rest.

So you leave the nice, friendly
elf village, turn two corners,

and then be fighting monsters again,
with nary a velvet rope betwixt the two.
In short,

there&#39;s something very unreal about this
magical dragons and wizards fantasy world.
As for the core gameplay,

you&#39;ll probably already know how
you&#39;ll feel about it when I reveal

that the two NPC party members that join
you in battle don&#39;t have health bars.
They just don&#39;t die, ever.
Sort of makes one wonder

why we&#39;re in charge; maybe
it&#39;s like the Sonic and Tails

arrangement where we&#39;re just the
one with the most self-esteem.

We can order the party members
to attack specific targets,

but it hardly seems worth it; combat
usually turns into a chaotic free for all,

and you&#39;ll be kept busy enough
dodging your own fat arse
out of the way of things.

The only use for NPCs is to make them
cast specific spells that combine

with specific status ailments
to do a big damage blast,

and I feel like we could&#39;ve achieved
that by stealing their magic wand and
Scotch taping it to our leg.

Otherwise, it hardly seems to matter
which NPCs you pick for your party

unless you&#39;re really committed
to knobbing one of them.

So if you were keen on the
strategic element of BioWare combat,

then it&#39;s a bit of a wash,
but it&#39;s generally fine

if you&#39;re an antisocial narcissist like me
who only cares about themselves.

Although I am annoyed that I&#39;m
still obliged to spend my party

members&#39; upgrade points and
pick their equipment for them.

Don&#39;t know why they
leave that all to me.

Maybe they&#39;ve noticed my
mini-map as well.
Combat gets very samey since

basically every enemy
faction has the same units:

Mr. Fast and Stabby,
Mr. Big Shield, and Mr.

Ranged Combat Standing at the Back
Being a Massive Prick All the Time.

Every now and again, things are
broken up with a tentpole story

boss fight, but not often
enough for my tastes,

and even these are rather
obnoxiously padded out.

I&#39;m thinking of one where you
fight a dragon of &quot;age&quot; fame,
and after you kill it,

the villain goes, &quot;NUH UH,&quot; brings it
back to life, and spawns a second one.

Which I wouldn&#39;t have minded,
but the thing clearly wasn&#39;t

designed to work in pairs; stupid berks
kept clipping through each other,

and I couldn&#39;t tell that one
was getting its projectile

attack ready because the other one was
in the way, noshing my reproductive organs.

So in the end, I guess I can&#39;t
recommend Shagging Abe Vigoda.

There&#39;s nothing particularly
new or exciting on the story

or gameplay level, and overall,
it&#39;s too flimsy and drawn out,

like a very tall person wearing
a very short person&#39;s pajamas.

I just kinda stopped before
the end &#39;cos I realized

I didn&#39;t really give a shit if the
elven gods took over the world.
I was like Australia in World War 2

when Japan was threatening
to invade northern Queensland.

If you can figure out what to do
with it, then help yourself, guys.
We only use it for twat storage.

Today’s credits monologue is meant solely
for Second Wind Patreon subscribers.

Everyone else, bugger off, okay?
Go watch Unpacked or something.
Have they gone? Right.

I just want to say, on the eve of Second
Wind’s second full year as a YouTube

channel, just how grateful I am
to all of you for making this happen.

Your generous monthly donations are
what fuel the engine of this crazy ride

we’re on, and you’re all quite
good looking and fundamentally

better human beings than all those
selfish, freeloading bastards.
Yeah, I know you heard me,

non-Patreon subscribers. That&#39;ll teach
you to do as you’re told, won&#39;t it?
